en_results_raw: He had written it in a fit of anger and excitement, the pen scratching furiously against the paper, his mind racing with the forbidden thoughts. The words were a declaration, a scream against the oppressive regime that sought to control every aspect of life, every thought, every emotion. The act of writing them down was a rebellion in itself, a small but significant act of defiance. As he stood there, the enormity of what he had done began to sink in. The diary, his secret repository of truth, now lay exposed, its pages filled with treasonous words. Winston knew that if discovered, it would mean certain death. Yet, in that moment, the fear was overshadowed by a strange sense of liberation. The act of writing "DOWN WITH BIG BROTHER" had been cathartic, a release of the pent-up frustration and hatred he harbored for the Party and its leader. It was a declaration of his individuality, his humanity, in a world where both were systematically eradicated. The risk was immense, but so was the potential for change, for revolution. As he turned the doorknob, Winston felt a mix of terror and exhilaration. The future was uncertain, but for the first time in years, it held the promise of something different, something better. The diary, with its damning words, was a symbol of that promise, a beacon of hope in the oppressive darkness.

But there were other fragments of memory that he was quite unable to fit into this picture. There was a memory of sitting on a horse, of riding along a country lane, of how the horse had leapt over a gate, and of a feeling of excitement. And there was another fragment: a momentary glimpse of the chessboard, of his small white hand moving a pawn and of crushing a piece of white paper into a ball. But it was all extraordinarily vague. It was like looking into an empty pool under glazed ice. And suddenly, while his mind made these uncertain forays into the past, there came a moment of dazzling understanding. He had not merely forgotten the diary: he had actually written it down in order to forget it. The act of forgetting, once the thought was there, could be performed mechanically. He might remember the diary for years ahead, and then suddenly decide to forget it, when it had served its purpose. And if the Party could thrust its instrument of torture into the brain, it would not only kill you, it would annihilate every trace of your existence, even from the memories of those you loved. The one thing that the Party could not do was to obliterate the past completely. It never had, and never could, existed. He who controlled the past controlled the future. The past was whatever the Party chose to make it. It controlled not only the future but the past. Whatever was true now was true from everlasting to everlasting. It was impossible to see reality except by looking through the eyes of the Party. He had no evidence that he had ever written the diary, and if the Party said that he had not written it, then that was true. Who controlled the past controlled the future: who controlled the present controlled the past. And yet the past, though of its nature alterable, never had been altered. It was a great formidable cry of anger and despair, a deep, loud “Oh-o-o-o-oh!” that went humming on like the reverberation of a bell. His heart had leapt. It’s started! he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking loose at last! When he had reached the spot it was to see a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of a street market, with faces as tragic as though they had been the doomed passengers on a sinking ship. But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls had been selling tin saucepans. They were wretched, flimsy

The successful women, bumped and jostled by the rest, were trying to make off with their saucepans while dozens of others clamored round the stall, accusing the stallkeeper of favoritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst of yells. Two bloated women, one of them with her hair coming down, had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of one another’s hands. For a moment they were both tugging, and then the handle came off. Winston watched them disgustedly.
